paragraphs.text: Five reasons why European Central Bank's QE won't save continent's dying economies.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: The European Central Bank has just announced a EUR60 billion ($69 billion) monthly government bond buying program--Quantitative Easing
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: that won't do much for the moribund continental economy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Central banks can print money to purchase government bonds to push up prices and lower interest rates on those assets and competing debt, such as corporate bonds and bank loans
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the United States, the Federal Reserve also bought billions in federally-sponsored mortgage-backed securities, such as those issued by Fannie Mae
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The aim is to encourage more borrowing by businesses and homebuyers-- stimulus spending financed by running the printing press
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Fed enjoyed some success boosting U.S  growth
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: here are five reasons why QE won't work for the ECB
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Eurozone Is Not a Country
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: The European Union does not have a large budget and issues few euro-denominated bonds the ECB could purchase
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Instead, the ECB will have to purchase individual country debt
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it is as if the Fed had to purchase a basket of bonds issued by California, Iowa and other states
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Markets for European bonds--both sovereign and corporate--and bank lending are highly fragmented along country lines
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Consequently
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: it is unlikely that QE will have much effect on banks' willingness to make new business loans in places buffeted by the financial crisis, like Spain and Greece
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: EU Has No Fannie Mae
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: QE seems to work best when central banks inject capital directly into specific markets
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Fed purchased mortgage-backed securities that significantly lowered interest rates on mortgages across America
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Housing prices recovered much of the value lost during the financial crisis
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: new home construction rebounded
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The EU has no analog to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the ECB cannot readily purchase mortgage-backed securities to boost the European housing sector
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Fiscal Policy Is Pulling in the Opposite Direction
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Europe's largest economy, Germany, recently accomplished a balanced budget for the first time since 1969
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: austerity programs intended to restore solvency have forced massive government spending cuts and tax increases in Spain, Greece and other Mediterranean states
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Those spending cuts-- though essential to sorely needed structural reforms-- will undercut the effects of any increased bank lending ECB bond purchase may induce
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With unemployment hovering at about 25 percent in Spain and Greece, and 13 percent in Italy, banks will remain skeptical that lending to expand businesses will do much to create bigger markets for what they sell
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: QE Does Little to Fix Euro-Imposed Dysfunctions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Although structural reforms could make Greece, Italy and other high unemployment economies more attractive places to build factories and establish businesses in the long run, governments in Athens, Rome and other capitals face voters who need jobs now
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And the cost of labor--though perhaps gradually falling--in these countries will remain too high to attract investment for many years
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Mediterranean countries still had their own currencies
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: , those could let their currencies fall in value relative to those of northern European states
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: That would re-price labor to attract investment and jobs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But the single currency, the euro, deprives them of that lever
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Absence of Pan European Institutions
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Though the Europeans have a single currency, they lack common education standards and language that gives the United States a more or less single labor market
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the absence of currency devaluation to re-price Mediterranean labor, Greeks, Italians and Spaniards cannot migrate to Germany where unemployment is only 5 percent, with the same ease that Americans have migrated to South Dakota and Texas to participate in the oil boom
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the end, the EU and ECB lacks what the Fed enjoys--the punch of a national government that ran large deficits to augment its efforts to pull the U.S  economy out of recession and national credit, housing and labor markets that made monetary policies--like QE--reasonably effective
paragraphs.label: assumption
